Description: Fragment of a block carved from black basalt. Block from the soubassement of the temple of Amun-Ra, inscribed and decorated in sunk relief. Under a continuous strip of sky with stars, representation of a quadripartite geographic procession. Personifications of districts of Lower Egypt (groups of four representing each nome) walking towards, alternating male 'Nile' gods (1 partially preserved) and goddesses (1 partially preserved). Each bears on their head the sign of a nome of Lower Egypt as well as offerings on their outstretched hands. To each deity belongs a hieroglyphic inscription of six columns. The goddess on this block represents nome 12 and the male figure the 'pehu' (swampy area) of nome 11. Above and in between the nomes’ personifications is a hieroglyphic inscription incised in ten vertical columns.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Museum August Kestner, Hannover. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

This inscribed block was bought at the same time as 1970.38 by the Kestner-Museum. The two fragments belong to the lower course of the temple of Amun-Ra in Naukratis, built by Ptolemy I Soter I and whose cartouches appear in the inscription. The composition and the inscription relate these blocks to three others, once kept in the Museum of Tanta (Tanta Museum 1016, 983+988+991+994+1002, and one block unnumbered), nowadays in Tell Basta deposit. A last block decorated with ‘androgynous Nile-figures’ bringing offerings, seen in the village of El-Noqrash, could pertain to the same monument (mentioned by Griffith in Gardner 1888, 80; Griffith 1890, 69). The Hannover blocks could be the ones mentioned by Edgar (Edgar 1922, 2), as seen by Daressy in Gabaris, 2,3 km to the south of the site (near Ezbet el-Akara): “M. Daressy tells me that he has seen some fragments of a similar kind at Gabares in the same neighbourhood”. The decoration of the temple of Amun is under study by D. von Recklinghausen.
